intro: Chavica mullesua var. guigual, commonly known as the Guigual chavica, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and has hairy, lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers range in color from white to pink and are often visited by pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
